image.altText: A man with long, blonde, curly hair, poses and smiles at a camera, wearing a pattern shirt, standing in front of a window.

items.synopsis: Scott White was arrested in 2020 over Scott Johnson's death, decades after the then-27-year-old's body was found at the base of cliffs in Manly near a gay beat.

title.children: Sydney man jailed for nine years over manslaughter of Scott Johnson

image.altText: The tail of a Jetstar and Qantas plane

items.synopsis: Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce says the new Western Sydney Airport will be the most technologically advanced and efficient in Australia when it opens in late 2026.

title.children: Qantas and Jetstar first airlines to fly domestically from Sydney's new $5.3b airport

image.altText: For Sale signage outside a suburban house.

items.synopsis: New research shows more than 25 per cent of homes sold in Queensland, Victoria and NSW were paid for in cash by older Australians who have benefited from high property prices and are "basically immune" to the effects of rising interest rates.

title.children: With another interest rate rise, there's a large group of home buyers 'immune' from its impacts

image.altText: A young woman with red lipstick smiles while hugging her grandmother

items.synopsis: Around one in three families has multiple generations living under the same roof. Cost of living could see that figure increase.

title.children: Young people are moving back in with their families — and it's not just them benefiting

image.altText: A middle-aged white man with grey hair and glasses wearing a suit speaks in a public place with a cityscape behind him.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese faces questions on whether he coordinated with Brittany Higgins over her allegation of rape, which was never proven, and claims of a cover-up by the former government.

title.children: Anthony Albanese faces questions on whether he planned with Brittany Higgins to pursue Coalition

image.altText: A man wearing a hooded jumper is walked towards a brick building by a police officer.

items.synopsis: The 37-year-old was arrested at a house in Bowraville on Thursday morning after a five-year investigation by task force detectives.

title.children: Man charged with murder of baby girl in country NSW in 2018

image.altText: Aryna Sabalenka and Alexander Lukashenko.

items.synopsis: Aryna Sabalenka is "not an expert in politics" and never has that been more apparent than when she denounced a war and an autocratic strongman with a history of revenge.

title.children: Europe's last dictator celebrated this young tennis star. Then Aryna Sabalenka publicly disowned him

image.altText: Before and after images show the flood damage

items.synopsis: Satellite images show the extent of the damage as one of the biggest reservoirs of water in the world drains across war-ravaged Ukraine.

title.children: A flood of biblical proportions: Southern Ukraine will be inundated with 36 Sydney Harbours in days

image.altText: Three tall buildings at the end of a road

items.synopsis: A row over a proposed 855-dwelling development which would house 2,000 residents at Zetland is being seen as a test for the New South Wales government in the battle over Sydney development.

title.children: Sydney needs more homes — but for some in this part of town, development is a dirty word

image.altText: Young school kids puts traditional paint on teacher's face

items.synopsis: The first bilingual Indigenous language school in NSW and its founding corporation want the Voice to Parliament to focus on language and truth-telling.

title.children: Hundreds of Indigenous languages are no longer spoken. This school hopes the Voice will ensure no more are lost

image.altText: A composite image of Jim Chalmers and Philip Lowe.

items.synopsis: It's not just stretched borrowers being pushed closer to breaking point. The consensus between the treasurer and the RBA governor is also cracking – at least when it comes to the impact wages are having on inflation, writes David Speers.

title.children: When it comes to inflation and wages, Chalmers and Lowe diverge on one pivotal point

image.altText: Albanese smiles on a cold morning, the autumnal red leaves of the Budget Tree creating a backdrop behind him.

items.synopsis: As economists warn the prospect of keeping the economy on "an even keel" has further diminised, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says he is optimistic the economy can ride out inflation.

title.children: Anthony Albanese says he's optimistic about the economy, as interest rates bite and recession warnings grow

image.altText: Former president Donald Trump claps his hand together at rally in Manchester, New Hampshire.

items.synopsis: Federal prosecutors have notified former US president Donald Trump's attorneys that he is the target of an investigation into his handling of classified materials, adding to his legal troubles as he campaigns for the White House in 2024.

title.children: Trump lawyers notified that former US president is the target of classified documents probe

image.altText: People standing under a bridge with orange haze around them

items.synopsis: Eerie images of New York City's skyline veiled by a layer of yellowish haze resemble scenes from science fiction film Blade Runner 2049. But why and how is it spreading so far?

title.children: Canadian wildfire smoke has engulfed the US east coast. How did they start and why is it travelling so far?

image.altText: A wing of plane with Rex written on the side of it

items.synopsis: Those onboard a delayed Rex Airlines flight intending to travel from Perth to Monkey Mia were told mid-flight the plane wouldn't be stopping and they would need to find their own way to their destination.

title.children: Rex Airlines skips scheduled stop mid-flight, leaving passengers stranded

image.altText: Two people hold hands in front of a rainbow flag.

items.synopsis: Japan's Fukuoka District Court makes a ruling on same-sex marriage that falls short of marriage-equality activists' expectations.

title.children: Japan court rules not allowing same-sex marriage is 'in a state of unconstitutionality'

image.altText: Toilets have been ripped out of walls in a damaged prison cell

items.synopsis: A mental health crisis amongst detainees, 'neglected' hygiene and living conditions as well as infrastructure in a 'state of disrepair' are among the serious issues discovered at WA's only youth detention centre.

title.children: Hygiene and living conditions 'neglected', infrastructure in 'state of disrepair' at WA's only youth detention centre

image.altText: Cyril Rioli celebrates a Hawthorn goal

items.synopsis: Brisbane Lions coach Chris Fagan backs his relationship with Cyril Rioli, after the former Hawks star identified himself as one of the complainants in the Hawthorn investigation.

title.children: 'We had a great friendship': Fagan says his relationship with former Hawks star was 'positive'

image.altText: A fire ant nest in Ipswich

items.synopsis: The "super pest" has so far been confined to south-east Queensland since its discovery there in 2001, but has crept 10 kilometres closer to NSW since 2017.

title.children: Can Australia beat this super pest? Fears fire ants could spread beyond south-east Queensland

image.altText: A group of men celebrate winning a grand final

items.synopsis: Jarrod Croker has become a Canberra Raiders legend en route to his 300th NRL game but before he was anything else in rugby league, he was a 16-year-old premiership winner with the Goulburn Stockmen.

title.children: 'He wanted to keep the premiership dirt on him': How a small town and big dreams were the making of Jarrod Croker

image.altText: Bird's eye view of rows of newly built houses with green lawns and solar panels on roofs.

items.synopsis: Rental advocates call for mandates requiring landlords to install solar panels on tenants' roofs amid warnings renters are missing out on the benefits of green energy.

title.children: Landlords should be forced to put solar panels on tenants' roofs: rental advocates

image.altText: A woman sitting in the dark.

items.synopsis: It's hoped 27 new refuge centres to be built across regional New South Wales will help more than 3,000 women and children leave abusive relationships. See the locations.

title.children: Dozens of new refuges to give domestic violence survivors 'somewhere safe to go'

image.altText: picture of a Russian officer looking at a bomber airplane on the ground

items.synopsis: Japan and South Korea scramble fighter jets after two Russian bombers join two Chinese bombers flying over the Sea of Japan as far as the East China Sea.

title.children: Japan and South Korea scramble aircraft in response to joint patrols by Chinese and Russian bombers

image.altText: Three images of Shannen Doherty having a mask placed over her head and mouth.

items.synopsis: Despite a mastectomy, radiation and chemotherapy, the Beverley Hills  90210 actor says her breast cancer has spread to her brain.

title.children: 'This is what cancer can look like': Shannen Doherty shares candid radiation treatment video

image.altText: A woman holds her hand to ear to get the crowd to cheer louder.

items.synopsis: Polish star Iga Swiatek sees off Coco Gauff, as Beatriz Haddad Maia becomes the first Brazilian woman since 1968 to reach a grand slam semifinal.

title.children: Iga Swiatek dominates American again, as Brazilian breaks 55-year grand slam hoodoo

image.altText: A large crocodile resting in the sun on a muddy bank

items.synopsis: Authorities are investigating the decapitations of two crocodiles in weeks, including a decades-old female well-known to tour operators in Queensland's far north.

title.children: Daintree croc tour favourite Lizzie's butchered remains prompt probe into suspected illegal killings

image.altText: A rugby coach gestures during a training session

items.synopsis: Wallabies coach Eddie Jones says he will coach the Wallabies to the 2027 World Cup, despite earlier comments to the contrary.

title.children: 'There's always two sides': Eddie Jones says he is committed to long-term Wallabies future

image.altText: Former Vice President Mike Pence speaks at a Coolidge and the American Project luncheon.

items.synopsis: Mike Pence has become the first US vice-president in modern history to challenge the president under whom he served.

title.children: Donald Trump 'should never be president': Mike Pence slams former boss at campaign launch

image.altText: People walk past Westpac branch with red signage in Brisbane CBD

items.synopsis: Westpac says it's receiving more hardship calls from mortgage borrowers as rate hikes continue, while the ASX loses ground as economists weigh a possible recession in Australia. Follow live.

title.children: Westpac fielding more mortgage hardship calls as rate hikes hit, property sector slides on the ASX

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This may not seem like content for a markets blog, but it's important in the context of wages, inflation, and productivity. The Bureau of Statistics has released its latest industrial disputes data today. It shows the number of industrial disputes, and the number of days lost to industrial disputes, fell significantly in the March quarter. It shows only 7,700 working days were lost to disputes in the March quarter, a decrease from 21,000 in the December quarter. If you see in that graph, you'll notice that industrial disputes have been dramatically lower since 1992 and 1993, after some changes to industrial laws by the Keating Government and the introduction of the inflation targeting era. If you take industrial disputes as a proxy for workers' ability to command higher wage increases, it shows how they've progressively declined over recent decades. Economic authorities were worried about that recent uptick in the industrial disputes, hoping it wasn't going to lead to higher pay increases and more disruption during this inflation crisis. But there's no sign that that uptick has been sustained. We're back to exceptionally-low levels.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Industrial disputes down in March quarter

children.content: This may not seem like content for a markets blog, but it's important in the context of wages, inflation, and productivity.
The Bureau of Statistics has released its latest industrial disputes data today.
It shows the number of industrial disputes, and the number of days lost to industrial disputes, fell significantly in the March quarter.
It shows only 7,700
working days were lost to disputes in the March quarter, a
decrease from 21,000
in the December quarter.

If you see in that graph, you'll notice that industrial disputes have been dramatically lower since 1992 and 1993, after some changes to industrial laws by the Keating Government and the introduction of the inflation targeting era.
If you take industrial disputes as a proxy for workers' ability to command higher wage increases, it shows how they've progressively declined over recent decades.
Economic authorities were worried about that recent uptick in the industrial disputes, hoping it wasn't going to lead to higher pay increases and more disruption during this inflation crisis.
But there's no sign that that uptick has been sustained. We're back to exceptionally-low levels.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Tony Sycamore, an analyst at IG, says the ASX200 Property Sector is getting hit this morning. It's down 1.6%. Domain Group (-3.01%), Stockland Group (-2.45%), Dexus Group (-1.8%), and GPT Group (-1.7%). In his note he says: "All things being equal, higher interest rates negatively impact real estate values. For integrated property groups such as Goodman Group, who own, develop, and manage properties, raising funds in an environment of rising interest rates can be a challenge, as is raising rents and increasing profits. "For owners of shopping centres, such as Stockland Group who have retailers as tenants - in the current environment of soft trading updates, retailers simply cannot afford to pay higher rent. "Furthermore, presuming the current consumer slowdown continues and costs increase (higher wages), retailers’ earnings will likely continue to fall and will soon result in profit warnings and eventually requests for rent reductions. "All of which is a direct result of the impact of higher interest rates. As noted above, when taming inflation is the priority, nothing else matters." He's included this chart to show the Property Sector index has performed since the start of 2022.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Property sector taking a hit today

children.content: Tony Sycamore, an analyst at IG, says the ASX200 Property Sector is getting hit this morning.
It's down 1.6%.
Domain Group (-3.01%), Stockland Group (-2.45%), Dexus Group (-1.8%), and GPT Group (-1.7%).
In his note he says:

"All things being equal, higher interest rates negatively impact real estate values. For integrated property groups such as Goodman Group, who own, develop, and manage properties, raising funds in an environment of rising interest rates can be a challenge, as is raising rents and increasing profits.
"For owners of shopping centres, such as Stockland Group who have retailers as tenants - in the current environment of soft trading updates, retailers simply cannot afford to pay higher rent.

"Furthermore, presuming the current consumer slowdown continues and costs increase (higher wages), retailers’ earnings will likely continue to fall and will soon result in profit warnings and eventually requests for rent reductions.
"All of which is a direct result of the impact of higher interest rates. As noted above, when taming inflation is the priority, nothing else matters."
He's included this chart to show the Property Sector index has performed since the start of 2022.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Westpac says it's fielding significantly more home loan hardship calls as the Reserve Bank continues its most aggressive tightening of monetary policy in a generation. This week, the RBA raised the cash rate for a twelfth time to 4.1 per cent, its highest rate in more than a decade. Anna Bligh, CEO of the Australian Banking Association, says more customers are "thinking of what other options they might have" if rising rates make it "impossible" for some customers to keep up with their repayments. She encouraged borrowers who are struggling to call their bank to discuss their options sooner rather than later. "There are very practical ways that banks can help to ease the financial pressure, temporarily, for several months," she said. "They can put you on an interest-only arrangement, they can, in some cases, defer payments for a period of time." You can listen to the full interview between Hamish Macdonald and Anna Bligh via the RN Breakfast website .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Westpac receiving more home loan hardship calls

featuredLink.title: Rate rise impacts 'getting very difficult' for some, says Anna Bligh - ABC Radio National

children.content: Westpac
says it's fielding significantly more
home loan hardship calls
as the Reserve Bank continues its most aggressive tightening of monetary policy in a generation.
This week,
the RBA raised the cash rate for a twelfth time to 4.1 per cent
, its highest rate in more than a decade.
Anna Bligh, CEO of the Australian Banking Association,
says more customers are "thinking of what other options they might have" if rising rates make it "impossible" for some customers to keep up with their repayments.
She encouraged borrowers who are struggling to call their bank to discuss their options sooner rather than later.
"There are very practical ways that banks can help to ease the financial pressure, temporarily, for several months," she said.
"They can put you on an interest-only arrangement, they can, in some cases, defer payments for a period of time."
You can listen to the full interview between
Hamish Macdonald and Anna Bligh via the RN Breakfast website

image.altText: A light purple hollow circle on a background of lemon yellow.

items.synopsis: Australian-first laws banning unnecessary and irreversible medical procedures for intersex children pass in the ACT Legislative Assembly.

title.children: ACT passes nation-first ban on irreversible surgery for young intersex children

image.altText: A penguin sits on straw in a burrow

items.synopsis: Hundreds of the world's smallest penguins call the foreshore of the Tasmanian city of Burnie home, and they'll soon have more room to move following the reclamation of a car park.

title.children: Little penguins to reclaim Tasmanian car park as city-based population thrives

image.altText: Orange smoke rising from lava in volcano crater.

items.synopsis: Kilauea, one of the most active volcanoes in the world, began erupting after a three-month pause, displaying spectacular fountains of mesmerising, glowing lava.

title.children: Webcam captures spectacular images of burning lava as Kilauea volcano erupts in Hawaii
